body.p: By Rev Dr A Günzburg of Baltimore

As regards
The inhuman direct or indirect coercion employed to induce men to change
their religion practised by the followers of other religions Judaism maintains
an eminence and incomparable position; since neither during the whole period time of its flouri
shing state, nor in that of its decay can there be shown to have existed a single
period when proselyte making was the business of its professors. I must take
the liberty to refer to my own work*: "In Judaism is it an accepted doctrine that
man can be virtuous in every religion which is based on humanity, and can
for this reason obtain salvation. One or the other religion is indeed more calcu-
lated to promote virtue; but not one is void of all means to lead to this
result. If even therefore Judaism regards itself as an institution whereby
the true divine principle in man is best promoted in the children of Adam,
this is only to be regarded in the light that Judaism exists standing as a signal* for all
nations, that the spirit which emanates from the same may operate abroad
to purify the morals and customs of mankind; but no Jew could thereby
be justified to search in the conscience of others to represent to them as
contemptible that in which they had been born and educated, which their soul had
imbibed in a long series of years, which filled their spirit, which
they had regarded hitherto as the most sacred and honoured, and to wean
them from their intended faith by convert them to Judaism? The principle
of Judaism or the contrary is: Let all the nations walk each in the name of
his its god: the ordinances of its religion—; but let us walk in the way of our living
God and everlasting kingǂ. The whole care of Judaism ought to be directed to
the maintenance and ? of its own inward strength to revive the religious climes

within; but to impose our faith conviction on others, and to search for recruits
for our faith is regarded by our religion no less unworthy as than prejudicial
to the native freedom of man, than unjust and improper in itself. Wherefore
no one can bring with justice a change against Judaism that, notwith-
standing the length of the period of its existence as a religious power, and
the many political occurrences during the same, it was never given
to the making of proselytes."

Nay the fear is not only introducted from indulging in the desire for making
converts and the ? of souls; but in accordance forth with the passage cited
in Jebamoth 24 and 47 we are not only compelled to convince ourselves that it is
not worldly motives, to wit, prospect of gain, the attainment of an honourable
position in office, a love affair which induced a proselyte to claim admission
to the Synagogue; but we must be sure of the sincere conviction of the appli-
cant, and consequently of his love for our faith; we have therefore to obtain
the ? possible certainty on of this point to paint in shiny colours to the
proselyte the manifold duties consequent on the adoption of the Jewish
religion and the punishment then in practice of the same, and there to
call his attention to the oppressed situation and the deplorable circumstances
